text: get the story started when I got the
manuscript one rainy night in Soho and I
didn't know of course it'd been turned
down by 22 or something other publishers
and I took it home and read it that
night people often say how much do you
have to read before you know something's
good actually I think you know after two
or three chapters and and I was just
gripped I was gripped by Harry's
situation the thing that I really liked
about the story was the friendship um
you know I like the owls in the boarding
school and the magic and Hogwarts but it
was the friendship between the children
that really that really moved me I gave
the the manuscript to my daughter Alice
um the night I got hit and she couldn't
stop reading so I had to tear it off for
the next morning so well I think I'm
gonna buy this what do you think she
said is a good idea so I rang up the
agent and we haggled for you know 10
minutes on a relatively low amount of
money and I bought the first two books
and and that was that really that was
the end of perhaps the most significant
purchase made in publishing the last 50
years I laugh about it now but you know
he I never would have guessed well when
I first rang her up like many authors
they don't believe it it's a publisher
or ringing them they think it's a joke
so after I convinced I actually was very
cunning when I actually was ringing from
a publisher in London she um she would
she was lost for words I think and I
didn't know how long the journey had
been of course I didn't know how many
publishers had turned her down and
agents indeed so so yeah so and then I
invited her down to London
and she said yes yes yes so do you mind
a little bit of editor and she don't no
no no she said very very nervously how
do you feel about sequels and I said
well you know I think just get the first
one out first and then well we'll think
about that but then she proceeded to
tell me the story of all the book
and how Harry would actually grow up
that was very kind revolutionary in
those days because mostly sequels would
just be the same book set in a different
environment but I was worried you know
she'd um she she was a single mom she
had no real income children's books
weren't the gold mine in that they've
become now and so I gave her the in
famous advice really was that that she
would never make any money out of
children's books and she should really
think about getting a day job as well
after we published we started absolutely
to get the the feedback that this was
going down very well that children were
recommending it to each other that had a
very good critical response but you know
I don't think we realized I don't think
Joe realized probably for a year after
that that this phenomenon was growing as
fast as it did and that's when she got
huge number of offers from the United
States and they paid very large amount
of money for the American rights and I
think it's that point we realized that
something was changing in the in the
world of children's books there's no
question it's a publishing phenomenon
some of the people here have been
queuing for 18 hours that if you like
Beatlemania for Pottermore began
I also remember that after the third
book was published in in the United
States she said she said I had a dream
last night and it was about the first
meeting that we had that it never
happened that that you never took the
book you never published it and the
whole thing still seems to me like a
wonderful dream and and really the story
of Harry Potter is like its own story it
is a kind of fairy tale listen carefully
and you can even hear it breathing these
